TopicTitle: [Linux] KSP fails to launch on my system, regardless of game version

Articles.Content:
Attempting to launch the game results in the window being generated, followed by an immediate CTD.

System specs are as follows:

  • Kubuntu Linux 18.04
  • Kernel version 4.15.0-43
  • Mesa drivers v18.0.5
  • i7-4770
  • 16GB DDR3
  • Gigabyte B85M
  • RX-480 4GB

Crash log here: 

[LOG 21:34:42.029] ******* Log Initiated for Kerbal Space Program - 1.6.0.2395 (LinuxPlayer) en-us *******
Kerbal Space Program - 1.6.0.2395 (LinuxPlayer) en-us


OS: Linux 4.15 Ubuntu 18.04 64bit
CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4770 CPU @ 3.40GHz (8)
RAM: 16001
GPU: AMD Radeon (TM) RX 480 Graphics (POLARIS10 / DRM 3.23.0 / 4.15.0-43-generic, LLVM 6.0.0) (4056MB)
SM: 50 (OpenGL 4.5 (Core Profile) Mesa 18.0.5)
RT Formats: ARGB32, Depth, ARGBHalf, Shadowmap, RGB565, ARGB4444, ARGB1555, Default, ARGB2101010, DefaultHDR, ARGB64, ARGBFloat, RGFloat, RGHalf, RFloat, RHalf, R8, ARGBInt, RGInt, RInt, RGB111110Float, RG32, RGBAUShort, RG16


Log started: Sun, Dec 30, 2018 21:34:42

That's it, it literally just ends there.

This is a fresh OS installation, on a fresh KSP installation (never modded, never even played until the update had completed downloading).

I've tried:

  • reinstalling the game
  • verifying the integrity of the files through steam
  • deleting the settings.cfg so it would re-generate (it does do that, thankfully)
  • making sure my entire system is up to date
  • Removing the MH DLC via steam
  • Launching the game in both 32 bit and 64 bit modes via standalone (i.e. not through steam)
  • Launching the game through the launcher
  • Launching with -force-opengl
  • Downgrading the game to 1.5.1

 

But so far nothing has worked. Any help is appreciated.

Any ideas what that means and how to fix it?

Bumping. I would really like to get back into KSP but it simply does not work on my system.

Not everyone has fiber nor browses the forums on a desktop.

8 hours ago, Harry Rhodan said:

Another desperate shot in the dark: a short time ago someone got corrupted user settings for their DE and actually got the game to run from a new user.

Ok, what in the actual love...

Created a new account w/o admin privileges, was able to launch the original root user's install to the loading screen which would halt on "loading asset bundle definitions". Same result for copying the install to the new user's home folder. Neither produced logs.

Now here's the really lovey part: Now my original install works from the original root user's account. Loads all the way to the main menu!

So for anyone with the same problem: Create a new user, launch original install from there. Switch back to the root user and your install should work now.

Deleted new KSP installation and removed new user. Game now fails to launch on root user.

Attempting to reproduce the ability to run the game by creating another new user has failed. Game fails to launch under all circumstances in the same way as in the OP.

21 minutes ago, said:

I wonder if a KSP store copy would behave in the same way. 

This all keeps making me think it's a "permission denied" thing. Something is trying to access a file without the right privilege or the file being accessed has had it's permission settings modified for some reason. I have had different issues in different games and apps that forced me to start fresh. But, I wanted to backup the entire home folder to an external drive before I wiped my system drives for a new install. There were two folders that refused to copy because of permission issues - .mozilla and .steam. In the case of .mozilla, it wasn't a major issue, I worked around it. I have no clue why .steam wouldn't copy. It was only one file, I told mint to ignore the file and move on and copy the rest, but still. Why wouldn't the one file copy? Steam is doing something in there for some reason, probably has to do with DRM.

This leads me to more questions. Do you use Steam Play for any of your games? Have you allowed Steam to install proton? I haven't proved it yet, but I had no issues with my Mint install until I started experimenting with Steam play. Then weird stuff started happening. Could just be a coincidence.

I have allowed steam to install Proton, though I have yet to try to install or run any games with it. I'll try seeing if I can block/remove Proton altogether and see if that changes anything.

EDIT: Unchecking Steam Play in the settings and restarting Steam did not prove successful.

Edited January 5, 2019 by space-is-hard

SOLUTION FOUND:

Completely uninstalled Steam via: 

sudo apt purge steam

then manually deleted all folders involved with steam: 

sudo rm -rv ~/.steam*
sudo rm -rv ~/steam

then removed all associated libraries: 

sudo apt autoremove -y

then restarted my system and reinstalled steam: 

sudo apt update && sudo apt install steam

and DO NOT ENABLE PROTON/STEAMPLAY, as it seems to have been the problem. I'm going to submit a bug report to the steamplay/proton github once I've verified that it is the issue.
